subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
Unorthodox variant {{Han simp|觸|f=蜀|t=虫|nocap=y}} found in the Ming dynasty orthographic dictionary <big>《字學三正》</big>. Also found in 《{{w2|zh|宋元以來俗字譜}}》, a {{w|Variant Chinese character|variant forms}} dictionary compiled in 1930.

Eventually adopted as an official simplified character by the People's Republic of China in the 1956 {{w|Chinese Character Simplification Scheme}}. <!-- Refer https://zh.wikisource.org/wiki/漢字簡化方案 -->

subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
Found in the historical {{w|Kangxi dictionary}} published during the Qing dynasty and cited from 《{{w2|zh|古今注}}》, a narrative work on ancient China written by {{w2|zh|崔豹}} during the {{w|Jin dynasty (265–420)|Western Jin}} period (265–316 AD).

The scholars who compiled the Kangxi dictionary may have confused this character with <big>{{l|zh|𩶥}}</big> which is visually similar. <!-- See http://www.kangxizidian.com/kangxi/1468.gif and also https://zh.wikisource.org/wiki/古今注#魚蟲第五 -->
